abstract.text: The methods that an object adopts to manage data and provide cells for a table view.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Table views manage only the presentation of their data; they don’t manage the data itself. To manage the data, you provide the table with a data source object — an object that implements the

protocol. A data source object responds to data-related requests from the table. It also manages the table’s data directly, or coordinates with other parts of your app to manage that data. Other responsibilities of the data source object include:
Reporting the number of sections and rows in the table.
Providing cells for each row of the table.
Providing titles for section headers and footers.
Configuring the table’s index, if any.
Responding to user- or table-initiated updates that require changes to the underlying data.
Only two methods of this protocol are required, and they’re shown in the following example code.

code: // Return the number of rows for the table.
override func tableView(_ tableView: UITableView, numberOfRowsInSection section: Int) -> Int {
// Provide a cell object for each row.
override func tableView(_ tableView: UITableView, cellForRowAt indexPath: IndexPath) -> UITableViewCell {
// Fetch a cell of the appropriate type.

inlineContent.text: Use other methods of this protocol to enable specific features for your table. For example, you must implement the
method to enable the swipe-to-delete feature for rows.
For information about how to create and configure your table’s cells using your data source object, see

content.text: Specify the location of rows and sections

inlineContent.text: Table views communicate the location of cells to you using the
and
properties of
objects. Row and section indexes are zero based, so the first section is at index
, the second at index
, and so on. Similarly, the first row of each section is at index
, which means you need both the
and
values to identify a row uniquely. If your table has no sections, you need only the
value.

abstract.text: An object containing a list of indexes that bridges to ; use  when you need reference semantics or other Foundation-specific behavior.
An index number identifying a section in a table view or collection view.
An index number identifying a row in a section of a table view.
Construct and manage a graphical, event-driven user interface for your iOS, iPadOS, or tvOS app.
A representation of the state of the data in a view at a specific point in time.
A representation of the state of the data in a view at a specific point in time.
An advanced interface for managing a data source object.
An object that organizes, sorts, and localizes the data for a table view that has a section index.
A standard control that can initiate the refreshing of a scroll view’s contents.
A view controller that specializes in managing a table view.
The methods that an object adopts to manage data and provide cells for a table view.
Asks the data source to return the number of sections in the table view.
Asks the data source to return the titles for the sections of a table view.
Asks the data source to verify that the given row is editable.
Asks the data source whether a given row can move to another location in the table view.
Asks the data source for a cell to insert in a particular location of the table view.
Asks the data source to commit the insertion or deletion of a specified row.
Tells the data source to move a row at a specific location in the table view to another location.
Tells the data source to return the number of rows in a given section of a table view.
Asks the data source to return the index of the section having the given title and section title index.
Asks the data source for the title of the footer of the specified section of the table view.
Asks the data source for the title of the header of the specified section of the table view.
A protocol that provides advance warning of the data requirements for a table view, allowing you to start potentially long-running data operations early.
The object you use to manage data and provide cells for a table view.
The object you use to manage data and provide cells for a table view.
Store and fetch images asynchronously to make your app more responsive.

abstract.text: Create and configure cells for your table dynamically using a data source object, or provide them statically from your storyboard.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.

media-3148902.alt: Illustration that shows a table with multiple sections. The first section has an index of 0 and no row value. The nine rows in the first section have indexes between 0 and 8. The second section has an index of 1 and no row value. Its first row starts at index 0 again.

value.text: A list of indexes that together represent the path to a specific location in a tree of nested arrays.
